ARTICLE 132
Human Resource Director
 
132.01   Establishment of position.
132.02   Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Employment provisions - see Art.
151
 
 
132.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF POSITION.
   There is hereby established the office of Human Resource Director, which
shall be an executive office of the City. The Human Resource Director shall be
appointed by the Mayor, upon the recommendation of a panel appointed by the
Mayor, and which appointment shall then be confirmed by Council. The Human
Resource Director shall be appointed without a set term of office.
(Passed 5-26-94.)
132.02 DUTIES.
   The Human Resource Director shall be responsible for planning and developing
policies, regulations and procedures for implementing an effective personnel
program within the City of Vienna, including performance evaluations,
classifications and salary administration. The Human Resource Director shall be
further responsible for the daily operations of the personnel department,
administering the employee benefit plans, including retirement, health
insurance, life insurance, vacation leave, sick leave, workers' compensation
and unemployment compensation. The Human Resource Director shall further be
responsible for processing all new employees, terminating or retiring
employees, and shall maintain statistical records for completion of government
reports for OSHA, EEOC, U.S. Census Bureau and other required reportings. The
Human Resource Director shall also maintain and be responsible for personnel
applications, personnel files, personnel policy and procedure manual, and
classification plans, and shall further be responsible for processing
applicants for summer employment. The Human Resource Director shall also serve
as the coordinator for the Americans with Disabilities Act, unless otherwise
directed by Council.
(Passed 5-26-94.)
ARTICLE 133
Planning Commission
 
133.01   Created.
133.02   Purpose of article.
133.03   Composition, membership, vacancies.
133.04   Original appointments.
133.05   Officers.
133.06   Offices, facilities and expenses.
133.07   Meetings; quorum.
133.08    Powers and duties.
133.09    Plat approval fees.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code 8-24-1
Composition; organization - see W. Va. Code 8-24-4 et seq.
Powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8-24-14 et seq.
Preparation of comprehensive plan - see W. Va. Code 8-24-16
Approval of subdivision plats - see W. Va. Code 8-24-28 et seq.
Hearings on zoning amendments - see W. Va. Code 8-24-27
 
 
133.01 CREATED.
   There is hereby established a City Planning Commission.
(1965 Code §2-10)
133.02 PURPOSE OF ARTICLE.
   It is the object of this article to improve the present health, safety,
convenience and welfare of the residents of the City and to plan for the future
development to the end that highway systems be carefully planned, that new
community centers grow only with adequate highway, utility, health, educational
and recreational facilities, that the needs of industry and business be
recognized in future growth, that residential areas provide healthy
surroundings for family life, and that the growth fo the community is
commensurate with and promotive of the efficient and economical use of public
funds.
(1965 Code §2-11)
133.03 COMPOSITION, MEMBERSHIP, VACANCIES.
   The Planning Commission shall consist of nine members, who shall qualify by
knowledge and experience in matters pertaining to the development of the City
and who shall include representatives of business, industry and labor. Three-
fifths of all members shall be residents of the City for at least one year
prior to nomination. One member of the Planning Commission shall also be a
member of Council, and one member shall also be a member of the Administrative
Department of the City. The term of these two members shall be coextensive to
the term of office to which he has been elected or appointed, unless the Mayor
and Council, at the first regular meeting of each year, appoint others to serve
as the City's representatives. The remaining seven members shall be appointed
for terms of three years each, except those members first appointed as provided
in Section
133.04. They shall be nominated by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term only. (Ord. 0-
15-86. Passed 9-11-86.)
133.04 ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   For the original appointment of the five members of the Planning Commission
provided for in Section
133.03, one member shall be appointed for one year, two members for two years
and two members for three years. (1965 Code §2-13)
133.05 OFFICERS.
   At its first regular meeting in each year, the Planning Commission shall
elect from its members a president and vice-president. It shall designate a
member of the Commission to act as an advisory member of the County Planning
Commission and it may appoint a secretary. (1965 Code §2-14)
133.06 OFFICES, FACILITIES AND EXPENSES.
   Council shall provide the Planning Commission with suitable offices and
facilities and provide by appropriation a sum sufficient to defray the
reasonable expenses of the Commission to enable it to carry out its duties.
(1965 Code §2-15)
133.07 MEETINGS; QUORUM.
   The Planning Commission shall fix the time for holding regular meetings, but
it shall meet at least once in the months of January, April, July and October.
   The provisions of West Virginia Code 8-24-8 and 8-24-9 shall govern special
meetings and quorums. (1965 Code §2-16)
133.08 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Planning Commission shall have all powers and perform all duties
provided for in West Virginia Code Article 8-24, and such provisions are
incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference. (1965 Code §2-17)
133.09 PLAT APPROVAL FEES.
   The Planning Commission is hereby authorized to adopt a fee schedule to be
charged to applicants for plat approval, which fee schedule, when so adopted,
shall be submitted to Council for its approval. Upon such approval by Council,
the fees imposed under such Schedule shall be charged to those persons applying
for plat approval, such fees to remain in force until otherwise amended.
(Passed 1-28-93.)
ARTICLE 135
Library Board
 
135.01    Created.
135.02    Incorporation.
135.03    Composition; terms; filling vacancies; compensation.
135.04    Powers and duties.
135.05    Annual report.
135.06    Collection of fees; assessing fines; sale of surplus equipment.
135.07    Limitation on liability of City.
135.08    Expenditures.
135.09   Liability for willful retention of library property.
135.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to operate public library - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(38)
Authority to appoint library board - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(39)
Public libraries - see W. Va. Code Art. 10-1
 
 
135.01 CREATED.
   There is hereby established a public library board of directors, which may
hereafter be referred to as the Vienna Library Board. (1965 Code §2-23)
135.02 INCORPORATION.
   The Library Board shall be a corporation, and as such it may contract and be
contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded and have and use a
common seal.
(1965 Code §2-24 )
135.03 COMPOSITION; TERMS; FILLING VACANCIES; COMPENSATION.
   (a)    Number, Qualifications and Appointment. Council shall appoint to the
Vienna Public Library Board of Directors three qualified persons chosen from
the residents of the City of Vienna. To assist Council in the appointments, the
Mayor shall submit to Council prospective candidates. (Ord. 06-17. Passed 8-10-
17.)
   (b)    Term.
      (1)    The term of office of each of the members of the Board shall be
for five years from the first day of July following their appointment and until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
      (2)    Notwithstanding the foregoing, upon their first appointment under
this article, one member shall be appointed for one year, expiring June 30,
1968; one member shall be appointed for two years, expiring June 30, 1969; one
member shall be appointed for three years, expiring June 30, 1970; one member
shall be appointed for four years, expiring June 30, 1971; and one member shall
be appointed for five years, expiring June 30, 1972.
   (c)    Vacancies. Vacancies in the Board shall be immediately reported by
the Board to Council and filled by appointment by Council, and, if an unexpired
term, for the remainder of the term only.
   (d)    Removal. A director may be removed for just cause in the manner as is
provided for in the bylaws of the Board.
   (e)    Compensation. No compensation shall be paid or allowed any director.
(1965 Code §2-25)
135.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Directors of the City public library shall:
   (a)    Immediately after appointment, meet and organize by electing one
member as president and one as secretary, and such other officers as may be
necessary. All officers shall hold office for one year and shall be eligible
for reelection.
   (b)    Adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as are necessary for its own
guidance and for the administration, supervision and protection of the library
and all property belonging thereto as may not be inconsistent with the
provisions of this article.
   (c)    Supervise the expenditure of all money credited to the Library Fund.
All money appropriated or collected for public library purposes shall be
deposited in the City Treasury to the credit of the Library Fund, to be paid
out on the certified requisition of the Library Board, in the manner provided
by law for the disbursement of other funds of Council, or shall be deposited as
the library's Board of Directors shall direct and be disbursed by the officer
designated by that Board, such officer before entering upon his duties to give
bond payable to and in an amount fixed by the Board of the library, conditioned
for the faithful discharge of his official fiscal duties. The cost of such bond
shall be paid from the Library Fund. The books, records and accounts of the
Library Board shall be subject to audit and examination by the office of the
State Tax Commissioner.
   (d)    Lease or purchase and occupy suitable quarters, or erect upon ground
secured through gift or purchase, an appropriate building for the use of such
library; and have supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms or
buildings constructed, leased, or set apart for library purposes.
   (e)    Employ a head librarian, and upon his recommendation employ such
other assistants as may be necessary for the efficient operation of the
library.
135.05 ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Board of Directors shall make an annual report for the fiscal year
ending June 30, stating the conditions of the library property, the various
sums of money received from the Library Fund and all other sources, and how the
money was expended, the number of books and periodicals on hand, the number
added and withdrawn during the year, the number of books lent, the number of
registered users of the library, with such other statistics, information and
suggestions as may be deemed of general interest. A copy of this report shall
be sent to the State Library Commission.
(1965 Code §2-27)
135.06 COLLECTION OF FEES; ASSESSING FINES; SALE OF SURPLUS EQUIPMENT.
   The Board of Directors may fix, establish and collect such reasonable fees,
service and rental charges as may be appropriate; may assess fines, penalties,
damages or replacement costs for the loss of, injury to, or failure to return
any library property or material; and may sell surplus, duplicated, obsolete or
other unwanted materials or equipment belonging to the library. All moneys
received from these or other sources in the course of the administration and
operation of the library shall be deposited in the Library Fund and shall be
disbursed by the Board of Directors in the manner prescribed elsewhere in this
article.
(1965 Code §2-28)
135.07 LIMITATIONS ON LIABILITY OF CITY.
   Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing herein contained shall authorize the
Board to bind the City or to do any act which results in making the City liable
for any sum of money for any purposes without prior approval of Council.
(1965 Code §2-29)
135.08 EXPENDITURES.
   The Board shall maintain the expenditures for each fiscal year within the
appropriation made by Council and shall not incur or contract for any debt or
liability which will anticipate the levy or income of any future fiscal year.
(1965 Code §2-30)
135.09 LIABILITY FOR WILLFUL RETENTION OF LIBRARY PROPERTY.
   Whoever willfully retains any book, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet,
manuscript or other article belonging to any public library for thirty days
after notice in writing to return the same, given after the expiration of the
time that by the rules and regulations of the library such an article or other
property may be kept, shall be liable for damages, to be recovered by the
Library Board by appropriate proceedings before the proper court; the recovery
in each case to be paid to the proper office or custodian of the Library Fund.
The notice required hereby shall include a copy of this section.
(1965 Code §2-32)
135.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever willfully defaces or injures any building or furniture, or defaces,
injures or destroys any picture, plate, map, engraving, newspaper, magazine or
book, or subject of art, or any other article belonging to a public library,
shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section 101.99. (1965 Code §2-31)
ARTICLE 137
Board of Parks and Recreation
137.01   Created.
137.02   Composition; quorum.
137.03   Appointment and qualifications.
137.04   Term of office.
137.05   Filling vacancies; removal.
137.06   Officers; meetings.
137.07   Powers and duties.
137.08   Contributions for improvements.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to operate parks and playgrounds - see W.Va. Code 8-12-5(37)
Public recreation and playgrounds - see W.Va. Art. 10-2
Park regulations - see S.U. & P.S. Art.
951
 
 
137.01 CREATED.
   There is hereby established a public parks and recreation board, which shall
be known as the Vienna Board of Parks and Recreation. (Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-
99.)
137.02 COMPOSITION; QUORUM.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall consist of seven members, a majority
of whom shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.
(Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-99.)
137.03 APPOINTMENT AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Except as provided in Section
137.04, the Board of Parks and Recreation shall consist of:
      (1)   Two members who shall also be members of the Board of Directors of
the Recreation Association.
      (2)   Two members who shall be selected at large from the residents of
the City.
      (3)   The City Forester or any successor position.
      (4)   One member shall be a member of Council.
      (5)   One member shall be the Director of Parks.
   (b)   At least thirty days before the expiration of the term of office of
any member appointed from the Recreation Association, such body shall submit to
Council the names of two nominees and shall designate which of the nominees
shall be given first consideration for appointment by the Council. Council has
the right to appoint one of the nominees, giving first consideration to the
nominee recommended. In the event the Council sees fit to reject both nominees,
Council shall request an additional list from which to make the appointment.
   (c)   The Mayor or Council members shall nominate and Council shall appoint
the members to be appointed from the residents at large and from members of
Council.
   (d)   In the event Council is unable to make the appointments in the method
provided above, Council has the right to appoint such resident as it may deem
necessary to fill any expired term.
   (e)   Each member, with the exception of the City Forester and the Director
of Parks, shall be a resident of the City.
   (f)   In the event that the City does not employ a City Forester, that
position shall be selected at large from the residents of the City.
(Ord. 04-18. Passed 5-24-18.)
137.04  TERM OF OFFICE.
   (a)   The term of office of each of the members of the Board of Parks and
Recreation shall be for three years and until his successor is appointed.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, Council shall appoint all five members
of the first Board, whose terms begin on April 8, 1965. The term of one
Recreation Association member shall be for three years; the term of one
Recreation Association member and the term of the members at large shall be for
two years; and the term of the members from Council shall be for one year.
(Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-99.)
137.05  FILLING VACANCIES; REMOVAL.
   (a)   When a vacancy occurs on the Board of Parks and Recreation, Council
shall appoint a successor to fill the unexpired term.
   (b)   Any member of the Board may be removed by resolution of Council for
any cause arising from or affecting the performance of his duties as such
member. No resolution shall be adopted until after five days’ written notice to
the member to be removed.
(Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-99.)
137.06 OFFICERS; MEETINGS.
   (a)   The first Board of Parks and Recreation shall meet within ten days
after its appointment and then organize by electing a president, a vice-
president and a secretary, which latter officer need not be a member of the
Board, and by adopting rules for conducting the affairs of the Board.
Thereafter, the Board shall meet annually on the second Wednesday in January
and elect a president, a vice-president and a secretary to serve for one year.
   (b)   In addition to the annual meeting the Board shall meet on the second
Wednesday of each month and such other times as it shall deem necessary to
conduct the business affairs of the Board.
   (c)   The secretary shall keep an accurate record of all the affairs of the
Board.
   (d)   The City Treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of the Board.
(Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-99.)
   
137.07 POWERS AND DUTIES.   
   (a)   Council does hereby delegate to the Board of Parks and Recreation and
the Director of Parks management and control of all Parks, together with all
recreation facilities and activities therein, except the following duties and
responsibilities which are hereby delegated to the Department of Public Works:
the maintenance and repair of all streets within all the aforementioned parks.
   (b)   Except as may be inconsistent with the provisions contained in
subsection (a) hereof, the Board of Parks and Recreation and the Director of
Parks are hereby authorized to make and promulgate rules and regulations for
the government, management and operation of the internal affairs of the parks
and activities therein; to provide for and regulate the use of the parks and
activities conducted therein; to improve, construct, maintain and repair the
grounds and facilities; to fix charges and rates for use of the parks and
facilities; and to do any and all other things or acts which may in any way be
necessary or incidental to the use and enjoyment of the parks and facilities by
the general public as a place of beauty, education, entertainment and
recreation.
   (c)   The Board and the Director of Parks shall maintain the expenditures
for any fiscal year within the appropriation made by Council and shall not
incur or contract for any debt or liability which will anticipate the levy or
income of any future fiscal year.
   (d)   All bills and invoices for expenditures shall be approved by the
Director of Parks submitted to Council for approval and payment in the same
manner as other bills and expenditures of the City.
   (e)   All of the power and authority delegated to the Board and Director of
Parks is subject to approval, modification or rejection by Council.
(Ord. 6-99. Passed 8-12-99.)
137.08 CONTRIBUTIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS.
   (a)   Persons who desire to voluntarily contribute to the improvements of
City parks and recreation facilities shall be entitled to do so by indicating
the amount of such contribution on the monthly Municipal utilities bills and
all moneys received by the Treasurer of the City in payment of such bills which
represent the voluntary contributions as indicated thereon shall be deposited
in a separate and segregated fund to be separately accounted for, which moneys
shall be used and administered by the Board of Parks and Recreation for capital
improvements within the park system of the City.
   (b)   In order to effectuate the provisions of this section, the Treasurer
is hereby directed to amend and revise the Municipal utilities monthly bill in
order to enable individuals or persons desiring to make such contributions to
indicate the same thereon and the amount of such contribution. (Ord. 6-99.
Passed 8-12-99.)
ARTICLE 139
Mid-Ohio Valley Transit Authority
139.01   Policy declared.
139.02   Creation; organization and function of authority and board.
139.03   Compensation of members; expenses.
139.04   Corporate existence established.
139.05   Meetings; officers; employees; official bonds; records of authority.
139.06   Quorum; majority vote required.
139.07   Budget.
139.08   Powers and duties.
139.09   Fiscal liability of City.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Urban mass transit systems - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-27
 
 
139.01 POLICY DECLARED.
   It is the intent of this article to create an urban mass transportation
authority to facilitate the activities necessary to develop a comprehensive
plan, policy, planning and management capacity to effectively determine needs,
set goals, and objectives, develop and evaluate programs, and carry out
management activities necessary for the planning and implementation of an urban
mass transportation system in the City of Parkersburg and the City of Vienna.
   It is further declared that all of the authorized activities outlined in
West Virginia Code Article 8-27 insofar as the sections thereunder are
applicable to an urban mass transportation authority are hereby incorporated in
this article.
(11-25-75)
139.02 CREATION; ORGANIZATION AND FUNCTION OF AUTHORITY AND BOARD.
   There is hereby created an urban mass transportation authority for the
cities of Parkersburg and Vienna, entitled Mid-Ohio Valley Transit Authority,
and the management and control of the Authority, its operations, functions and
affairs, shall be vested in a Board of not less than five, nor more than
fifteen individuals who shall be known as members of the Board, and who shall
be appointed for terms of three years each by the Mayor of Parkersburg with the
advice and consent of Council of Parkersburg, and by the Mayor of Vienna with
the advice and consent of Council of Vienna. (8-11-77)
   The initial Board shall consist of seven members, five of whom shall be
appointed by the City of Parkersburg and two of whom shall be appointed by the
City of Vienna. One member of the initial Board shall be appointed for a term
of one year, two members of the initial Board shall be appointed for a term of
two years, and three members of the initial Board shall be appointed for a term
of three years. The initial appointment of the member from the City of Vienna
shall serve for an initial term of three years. As the term of each such
initial appointee expires, the successor who fills the vacancy created by the
expiration shall be appointed for a term of three years. Any individual who is
a resident of the City of Parkersburg, is eligible to serve as a member of the
board to represent that city. Any individual who is a resident of the City of
Vienna is eligible to serve as a member of the Board to represent that City.
The governing bodies of the respective cities represented shall inform the
Authority of its appointments or reappointments to the Board by delivering to
the Authority a certified copy of the ordinance or resolution making the
appointment or reappointment. If any member of the Board dies, resigns or for
any other reason ceases to be a member of the Board, the governing body of the
City represented by that member shall appoint another individual to serve the
unexpired portion of the term of such individual.
(11-25-75; 8-11-77; 11-17-95.)
139.03 COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS; EXPENSES.
   As compensation for his services on the Board, each member shall receive,
from the Authority, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each meeting actually
attended. The total compensation paid to any member by the Authority for any
fiscal year shall not exceed in the aggregate, the sum of six hundred dollars
($600.00). Each member shall also be reimbursed by the Authority for all
reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his
duties as a member of the Board.
(11-25-75.)
139.04 CORPORATE EXISTENCE ESTABLISHED.
   The Mid-Ohio Valley Transit Authority shall constitute a public corporation,
and as such shall have perpetual existence in accordance with the authority
established by West Virginia Code 8-27-4. (8-11-77.)
139.05 MEETINGS; OFFICERS; EMPLOYEES; OFFICIAL BONDS; RECORDS OF AUTHORITY.
   At its first meeting, to be held no later than sixty days from the creation
of the Authority, the Board shall elect from its membership a president to act
during the next ensuing fiscal year, or until his successor is elected and
qualified. At that time the Board shall also elect a vice-president, a
secretary and a treasurer and other officers as may be required, who need not
be members of the Board, whose duties shall be defined and whose compensation
shall be fixed by the Board and paid out of the funds of the Authority. The
treasurer, and other officers and employees as the Board shall direct, shall
furnish bond for the use and benefit of the Authority in such penal sum as may
be fixed by the Board and conditioned upon faithful discharge by the treasurer
and other officers and employees so directed by the Board of the duties of
their respective offices or employment, and upon accounting for and paying over
all moneys which may come into their possession by virtue of such office or
employment. At its first meeting, the Board shall also fix the time and place
for holding regular meetings, but it shall meet at least once in the months of
January, April, July and October. Special meetings of the Board may be called
by the president or by two members upon written request to the secretary. The
secretary shall send to all the members, at least two days in advance of a
special meeting, a written notice setting forth the time and place of the
special meeting and the matters to be considered at the special meeting.
Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special
meeting has been fixed in a regular meeting, or if all the members are present
at the special meeting. All regular meetings shall be general meetings for the
consideration of any and all matters which may properly come before an
authority. All proceedings of the authority shall be entered in a permanently
bound record book, properly indexed, and the same shall be carefully preserved
by the secretary of the Authority. All records of the Authority shall be public
records.
(11-25-75)
139.06 QUORUM; MAJORITY VOTE REQUIRED.
   A majority of the members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. The vote
of a majority of all members present at any meeting of the Board shall be
necessary to take any action. (11-25-75)
139.07 BUDGET.
   The Board shall establish the beginning and ending of its fiscal year, which
period shall constitute its budget year, and at least thirty days prior to the
beginning of the first full fiscal year after the creation of the Authority and
annually thereafter the treasurer shall prepare and submit to the Board a
tentative budget. The tentative budget shall be considered by the Board and,
subject to any revisions or amendments that may be determined by the Board,
shall be adopted as the budget for the ensuing fiscal year. No expenditures in
excess of the budget shall be made during the fiscal year unless expressly
authorized and directed by the Board. It shall not be necessary to include in
the budget any statement of necessary expenditures for annual interest or
principal payments on bonds or for capital outlays, but the Board shall make
provisions for their payment as they become due.
(11-25-75)
139.08 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and the duties of the Board shall be:
   (a)    To sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded.
   (b)    To have and use a seal and alter the same at pleasure.
   (c)    To make and adopt all rules and regulations and bylaws as may be
necessary or desirable to enable it to exercise the powers and perform the
duties conferred or imposed upon it by the provisions of this article.
   (d)    To employ, in its discretion, planning, architectural and engineering
consultants, attorneys, accountants, construction, financial, transportation
and traffic experts and consultants, superintendents, managers and other
employees and agents as may be necessary in its judgment, and to fix their
compensation.
   (e)    To acquire by grant, purchase, gift, devise or lease and to hold,
use, sell, lease or otherwise dispose of real and personal property of every
kind and nature whatsoever, licenses, franchises, rights and interests
necessary for the full exercise of its powers pursuant to the provisions of
this article or which may be convenient or useful for the carrying out of such
powers.
   (f)    To acquire, construct, reconstruct, complete, develop, improve, own,
equip, maintain and operate any system or systems, or any part thereof,
including without limitation, the power to acquire by purchase, lease or gift
all or any part of any licenses, franchises, rights, interests, engineering and
technical studies, data or reports owned or held by any person and determined
by its board to be necessary, convenient or useful to the Authority in
connection with the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, completion,
development, improvement, ownership, equipping, maintenance or operation of any
system or systems and to reimburse public utilities for relocation of any
utility line or facility made necessary by the construction, reconstruction,
completion, development, improvement, equipping, maintenance or operation of
any system or systems.
   (g)    To acquire any land, rights or easements deemed necessary or
incidental for the purposes of the Authority by eminent domain to the same
extent and to be exercised in the same manner as now or hereafter provided by
law for the right of eminent domain by business corporations.
   (h)    To enter into contracts and agreements which are necessary,
convenient or useful to carry out the purposes of this article with any person,
public corporation, state or any agency or political subdivision thereof and
the Federal Government and any department or agency thereof, including without
limitation, contracts and agreements for the joint use of any property and
rights by the Authority operating any system, whether within or without the
service area of the Authority, and contracts and agreements with any person or
authority for the maintenance, servicing, storage, operation or use of any
system or part thereof, facility or equipment on such basis as shall seem
proper to its Board.
   (i)    To enter into contracts and agreements for superintendence and
management services with any person, who has executive personnel with
experience and skill applicable to the superintendence and management of any
system, for the furnishing of its services and the services of experienced and
qualified personnel for the superintendence and management of any system or any
part thereof, including without limitation, superintendence over personnel,
purchases, properties and operations and all matters relating thereto, and any
revenue bond trust indenture may require such contract or agreement, but the
personnel whose services are to be so furnished under any such contract or
agreement shall not include any member of the Board, any member of the
immediate family of a member of the Board or any agents or employees of the
Authority, and no such contract or agreement shall extend beyond a term of ten
years or such longer time as there are outstanding any revenue bonds under a
trust indenture which requires the contract or agreement.
   (j)    To assume any lien indebtedness of any system or part thereof
acquired by it under the provisions of this article.
   (k)    To execute security agreements, contracts, leases, equipment trust
certificates and any other forms of contracts or agreements, granting or
creating a lien, security interest, encumbrance or other security in, on or to
facilities and equipment, containing the terms and provisions as the Board
deems necessary.
   (l)    To apply for, receive and use grants, grants-in-aid, donations and
contributions from any source or sources, including but not limited to, the
Federal Government and any agency or department thereof, and a state government
whose constitution does not prohibit such grants, grants-in-aid, donations and
contributions, and any agency or department thereof, and to accept and use
bequests, devises, gifts and donations from any person.
   (m)    To lease any system or any part thereof to, or contract for the use
of any system or any part thereof by, any person, but a trust indenture may
prohibit, limit or restrict the exercise of such power.
   (n)    To acquire for cash or in exchange for its bonds all or any part of
any publicly or privately owned system or systems.
   (o)    To make or cause to be made either by itself or in cooperation with
other persons or organizations, whether public or private, traffic surveys,
population surveys and such other surveys and studies as it considers useful in
the performance of its duties or the exercise of its powers under the
provisions of this article and in connection therewith the Authority may
contract with any person or organization for such planning services.
   (p)    To enter into contracts and agreements with any public or private
system either within or contiguous to its boundaries for the transfer of
passengers between it and the system operating in territory contiguous to its
boundaries.
   (q)    To fix and establish from time to time, subject to the approval of
the Public Service Commission, such fees, rates or other charges and routes,
time schedules and standards of service as will provide revenues in each year
at least sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on all bonds issued by
the Authority, and reasonable reserves therefor, as the same shall become due,
together with the cost of administration, maintenance, repair and operation of
the system or systems in each year, together with all other payments required
in each year by the resolution which authorized the issuance of the bonds, or
the trust indenture securing the same, including without limitation, reasonable
reserves or margins for any of such purposes, and every authority shall file
and keep on file the information specified in West Virginia Code 24A-6-2 in the
manner and form as therein provided.
   (r)    To issue revenue bonds of the Authority for any of its purposes or
projects and to refund its bonds, all as provided in this article.
   (s)    To encumber or mortgage all or any part of its facilities and
equipment.
   (t)    To prepare plans for and assist in the relocation of persons
displaced by the Authority and to make relocation payments to or with respect
to such persons for moving expenses and losses of property for which
reimbursement or compensation is not otherwise made, including the making of
such payments financed by the Federal Government.
   (u)    To do any and all things necessary or convenient to carry out the
powers given in this article unless otherwise forbidden by law.
   The exercise of any of the powers herein granted is expressly made subject
to the provisions of West Virginia Code Article 8-27, wherever the same are
applicable.
(11-25-75 )
139.09 FISCAL LIABILITY OF CITY.
   Nothing herein shall obligate the expenditure of levies of the City beyond
the present fiscal year, nor shall any provision of this article be interpreted
to involve payment of moneys from future tax levies of the City.
(11-25-75 )
ARTICLE 141
Building Inspector
 
141.01    Enforcement of Building Codes.
141.02    Building permits.
141.03    Additional powers.
141.04   Building Inspector Assistant.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
National Building Code - see BLDG. Code Art.
1721
Unsafe buildings - see BLDG. Code Art.
1735
 
 
141.01 ENFORCEMENT OF BUILDING CODES.
   The Building Inspector shall administer and enforce the Building Codes of
the City and all other laws, ordinances and regulations under which building,
construction and occupancy permits are required and shall conduct inspections
of properties throughout the City in connection with such administration and
enforcement. The Building Inspector shall have authority and power to issue
citations to any persons who violate such Building Codes, laws, regulations and
ordinances. (Ord. 0-27-87. Passed 7-23-87.)
141.02 BUILDING PERMITS.
   (a)   The Building Inspector shall have authority and power to receive all
applications for building permits and other permits related and required by the
Building Codes of the City and to determine whether the applicant is entitled
to such permit according to the laws, ordinances and regulations under which
such permit is required. The Building Inspector shall issue such permit if the
application is approved and the fee paid or notify the applicant in writing of
any refusal and the reasons therefor. The Building Inspector shall have plenary
authority to revoke, suspend or cancel any such permit which has been violated.
Notice of such revocation, suspension or cancellation shall be in writing and
shall state the reasons therefor. The Building Inspector shall perform such
other duties as required by resolution, ordinance or assigned by the Mayor.
(Ord. 0-27-87. Passed 7-23-87.)
   (b)   No building permit shall be issued, except as herein provided, unless
the applicant for such permit shall submit to the Building Inspector, in such
form and manner as the Building Inspector shall from time to time determine,
the following information:
      (1)   A complete set of drawings or blueprints or other suitable
description of the work to be performed as the Building Inspector may deem
necessary;
      (2)   A plat of the property upon which the location of the structure is
to be built with reference to all property and street lines, and indicating the
distances from such property and street lines which such structure shall
occupy;
      (3)   The correct names of general contractors which are expected to
perform work relating to the activities for which the permit is hereby sought,
which shall include all general contractors and copies of current state
contractors licenses for such contractors unless otherwise on file. (Note: For
the purpose of this section as stated in Section
757.04 “General contractor” means any person, firm, corporation or partnership
engaged in the business of performing for others, contracts for the
constructing, repairing, decorating or improving of new or existing buildings
or other structures under, upon or above real property either for the entire
work or a specific portion thereof.)
         (Ord. 6-22-95. Passed 6-12-97.)
      (4)   Vienna Stormwater Certification Course.  
         A.   In addition to any requirement set out elsewhere in this Article
and prior to the issuance of any Building Permit, the applicant shall submit
written proof of the completion of any Stormwater Certification Course offered
by either the City of Vienna or the Vienna Utility Board to the Building
Inspector. No Building Permit may be issued until such proof has been received
by the Building Inspector;
         B.   Any homeowner who is performing his or her own work upon his or
her own primary or principal residence is hereby exempt from this requirement;
         C.   Stormwater certification is valid for two years from the date
stormwater certification test or exam is passed.
            (Ord. 05-15. Passed 5-28-15.)
   (c)   Upon receipt of all of the information referred to in subsection (b)
hereof, the Building Inspector shall consider the application and, within five
days from such consideration, shall issue the building permit or deny the
application and provide unto the applicant the reasons for such denial.
   (d)   In connection with work to be performed solely by the property owner,
in those cases where a permit is otherwise required, the Building Inspector
shall receive a satisfactory drawing or other suitable description of the work
to be performed in such form and manner as the Building Inspector may, from
time to time, deem necessary.
   (e)   Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the Building Inspector from
submitting any information to BOCA for assistance in advance of the issuance of
the permit.
   (f)   All fees for building permits shall be set forth in Section 1309.02.
(Passed 6-22-95; 6-12-97.)
141.03 ADDITIONAL POWERS.
   The provisions contained herein shall not be construed as limiting the
powers, responsibilities and duties of the Building Inspector heretofore
existing, it being the intention of this article that the provisions provided
herein shall be in addition to and cumulative to any such existing duties,
powers and responsibilities provided by prior ordinances.
(Ord. 0-27-87. Passed 7-23-87.)
141.04 BUILDING INSPECTOR ASSISTANT.
   There is hereby created the position of “Building Inspector Assistant”; the
job description for this position is attached to Ordinance 0-4-03 and
incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 0-4-03. Passed 6-12-03.)
ARTICLE 143
Code Enforcement Officer
 
143.01    Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Powers of Building Inspector - see ADM.
141.01 et seq.
Outdoor fire permits - see FIRE PREV.
1509.01 
 
 
143.01 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Code Enforcement Officer shall administer and enforce the Fire Codes and
Building Codes of the City. The Code Enforcement Officer shall have the
authority and power to issue citations to any persons, who violate such Fire
Codes and Building Codes and to revoke, suspend or cancel any permit issued by
him which has been violated. Any notice of revocation, suspension or
cancellation of such permit shall be in writing and shall state the reasons
therefor. The Code Enforcement Officer shall, in addition to those other
officials designated by ordinance, have authority to issue permits for burning
as provided in Article 1509 of the Codified Ordinances. Any such permit for
burning issued by the Code Enforcement Officer shall be enforced by him in
accordance with the provisions contained herein. Nothing contained herein shall
be construed to limit the powers, duties and authority of Code Enforcement
Officer provided by ordinances adopted prior hereto.
(Ord. 0-28-87. Passed 7-23-87.)
ARTICLE 145
Building Commission
 
145.01   Established.
145.02   Members.
145.03   Appointment; term; vacancies.
145.04   Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code Art 8-33
 
 
145.01 ESTABLISHED.
   The. City hereby creates and establishes the City of Vienna Municipal
Building Commission, hereinafter referred to as "Commission".
(Ord. 0-12-89. Passed 8-10-89.)
145.02 MEMBERS.
   All powers, property and duties, and the management and control of the
Commission shall be vested in a Board consisting of three members.
(Ord. 0-12-89. Passed 8-10-89.)
145.03 APPOINTMENT; TERM; VACANCIES.
   (a)    The initial appointees of the Board, each of whom is found to be a
resident of the City shall be appointed for the following terms: one appointee
shall be appointed for an initial term of one year; the second appointee shall
be appointed for a term of two years; the third appointee shall be appointed
for a term of three years. As the term of each such initial appointee expires,
the successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be
appointed for a term of five years.
   (b)    Each appointment, including the appointment of the initial
appointees, shall be made by Mayor and Council, by majority vote. If any member
of the Commission shall die, resign, or for any reason cease to be a member of
the Commission, Council shall appoint another individual to fill the unexpired
portion of the term of such member. No more than two-thirds of the total number
of members of the Commission shall be from the same political party and no
member of the Commission shall hold any office or employment under the United
States of America, the State of West Virginia, any county or political
subdivision thereof, or any political party.
   (c)    All members of the Commission shall be residents of the City. No
member of the Commission shall receive any compensation for his services as
such, but each member shall be reimbursed by the Commission for any reasonable
and necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his duties as a
member of the Commission.
(Ord. 0-12-89. Passed 8-10-89.)
145.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commission shall be vested with all powers and authorities as more
specifically enumerated in West Virginia Code 8-33-4, as amended, including the
power of eminent domain, in the manner provided for in West Virginia Code
Chapter 54, without limitation or condition. (Ord. 0-12-89. Passed 8-10-89.)
ARTICLE 151
Employment Provisions
   EDITOR’S NOTE: The City of Vienna Employees’ Retirement Plan which
incorporates the original agreement for employees of the Water and Sewer
Departments dated February 15, 1964, as revised to include other employees, and
as amended on January 25, 1973, July 25, 1974, and January 9, 1975, was
approved by Council on February 26, 1976. Interested parties may consult the
Recorder for information pertaining to such Plan.
   Pursuant to a resolution passed on December 11, 2014, Council adopted the
“Personnel Policy and Procedures Manual” a copy of which is on file at City
Hall.
151.01   Vacations.
151.02   Holidays.
151.03   Holiday pay.
151.04   Sick leave.
151.05   Special leaves.
151.06   Health insurance.
151.07   Pay periods. (Repealed)
151.08   Drugs, narcotics and alcohol policy.
151.09   Leave donation program.
151.10   Equal Employment Opportunity Plan.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Oath - see W. Va. Code 8-5-8
Officers and employees generally - see W. Va. Code 8-5-11
Compensation - see W. Va. Code 8-5-12
Conflict of interests - see W. Va. Code 8-5-19
Retirement plans - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-22-2 et seq.
 
 
151.01 VACATIONS.
   (a)   Each employee having completed the following number of years of
continuous employment with the City shall, during the calendar year in which
his or her anniversary falls, be entitled to the following number of days with
pay.
      
 
Years of Service Days Accrued
1-5              10 days
6-10             15 days
11-15            20 days
16-20            25 days
21 and up        25 days, plus one day
                 per each year above 20
   (b)   An employee may elect to accumulate vacation leave to add to the
regular vacation leave to be taken in subsequent years, the number of days
which may be accumulated and the maximum number of days which may be
accumulated for the various years of employment shall be as follows:
 
                                   Total Vacation Days
                 Days Which May Be Which May Be
Years of Service Carried Over      Accumulated
1 thru 5         5 days            10 days
6 thru 10        10 days           15 days
11 thru 15       15 days           20 days
16 thru 20       20 days           25 days
21 and up        25 days           30 days
 
(Passed 6-12-97)
   (c)    The time for each employee's vacation shall be arranged and fixed by
the head of his department. (Passed 1-12-84.)
151.02 HOLIDAYS.
   All days set forth in West Virginia Code 2-2-1, as amended, are hereby
declared legal holidays for all fun time City employees. This section shall be
retroactive to March 5, 1988. (Ord. 0-7-89. Passed 4-13-89.)
151.03 HOLIDAY PAY.
   (a)    In the event it is necessary for an employee to work on a holiday,
the employee shall receive two and one-half times his regular rate of pay. If
the holiday is observed on one of the employee's regularly scheduled days off,
the employee shall receive pay for hours equivalent to regularly scheduled
hours of work or equal time off. An employee shall not be considered as having
regularly scheduled days off during periods of sick leave. If a holiday falls
within an employee's vacation period, the employee is entitled to one
additional day of vacation, or receive pay at employee's regular rate of pay.
   (b)    In order to qualify for pay for a holiday not worked, the employee
must have worked on his last regularly scheduled day of work prior to the
holiday and on their next regularly scheduled day of work following the
holiday. If the employee is scheduled to work on a holiday and does not work,
he shall receive no pay for the holiday.
(Passed 1-12-84. )
151.04 SICK LEAVE.
   (a)    Sick leave can be used for personal illness and serious illness in
the immediate family. It can be used in the event of a communicable disease
which endangers the health of others. Sick leave covers medical treatment and
check-up office visits and home care. Sick leave in excess of three days must
be verified by a physician's certificate.
(Passed 1-12-84.)
   (b)    Accrual of 1.25 days per month with pay shall be allowable annually
as sick leave to each full-time employee. The leave can be accumulated up to
fifteen days per year.
(Passed 6-12-97.)
   (c)   An employee shall have the right and option to convert up to thirty
days of accumulated sick leave to one-half regular pay, provided that not more
than thirty days may be converted in any calendar year and provided further
that no conversion may be made unless at least ninety days sick leave have
accumulated at the time of conversion.
(Passed 1-12-84)
   (d)   Any employee of the City who is otherwise eligible for retirement,
except for the fact that such employee has not reached his or her retirement
date shall, for the purposes of early retirement only, be entitled to convert
all unused accumulated sick leave to regular paid days, which such converted
days shall be credited and applied in determining compliance with all
retirement plans presently offered by the City or hereafter adopted. At the
time an employee elects to convert unused accumulated sick leave, as herein
stated, such employee shall not accumulate any additional sick leave, vacation
days and holiday pay benefits which would have accrued subsequent to the
election to convert.
(Ord. 0-6-88. Passed 6-9-88.)
151.05 SPECIAL LEAVES.
   (a)   Jury Duty. Employees required to serve on a jury before a court
empowered by law to require such service shall be excused from work for the
time required for such service and shall be paid the regular rate less jury
pay, provided the department head has been notified not less than three days
prior to such jury service date.
   (b)   Funeral Leave.
      (1)   Employees shall be granted three days’ leave with pay to attend the
funeral of a member of the immediate family, and one day for the funeral of a
relative not a member of the immediate family, with approval of the department
head. If the leave period includes a weekend, holiday or scheduled days off,
those days shall be included in the total days funeral leave to which the
employee is entitled.
      (2)   “Immediate family” means spouse, parent, child, brother, sister,
employee’s grandparent and employee’s mother-in-law and father-in-law.
      (3)   “Relative not a member of the immediate family” means an employee’s
son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law and sister-in-law.
   (c)   Exceptional Circumstances. Department heads, at their discretion,
shall have authority to grant one day’s leave with pay for exceptional
circumstances which, in the sole opinion of the Department head, justifies such
leave, provided that such leave during any calendar year shall not exceed one
day per employee.
(Passed 1-12-84)
151.06 HEALTH INSURANCE.
   (a)   Regular Employees. The City shall provide to its regular employees and
their spouses and dependents, a group policy or policies of insurance covering
health, hospital and medical treatment. The City and employees shall share in
the cost of the premiums thereon. Employees hired after the date of this
section shall be enrolled in the group health plan designated by the City as
the most cost efficient policy. The health insurance shall not be available to
provisional, temporary or emergency employees.
   (b)   Retirement; Death. At which times as a participating employee
(“employee” being defined herein as all regular employees, excluding those
covered under civil service) of the City shall retire from his or her
employment and is not less than fifty with no less than twenty years of
service, such employee may remain a member of the group insurance plan
designated by the City and retain coverage for his or her spouse and
dependents. Such retiring employee shall be required to pay one-half of the
premium cost for him (her) self and for his or her spouse and dependents and
the City shall pay the remaining one-half of the premium cost involved. Spouses
and dependents of any deceased member may also remain members of the group
insurance plan by paying one-half of the premium cost for such coverage and the
City shall pay the remaining one-half of the premium cost involved. If a spouse
of a deceased member should remarry, he or she would no longer be eligible for
the group insurance plan. Any termination of employment by a participating
employee due to a medically certified disability shall constitute retirement
for the purpose of remaining a member of the group insurance plan, and such
disabled employee and his or her spouse and dependents shall be eligible to
remain members of the group insurance plan by paying one-half of the premium
cost thereon, and the City shall pay the remaining one-half of such premium
cost; provided, however, that in the event such disabled employee should,
thereafter, obtain gainful employment, he or she and spouse and dependents
shall no longer be eligible to remain members of such group insurance plan and
any obligation on the City to pay any portion of the premium cost shall
terminate.
   (c)   Optional Retirement and Health Insurance. Employees hired prior to
January 1, 1997, shall have the option of using the former eligibility rules
pertaining to retirement and health insurance, to-wit: age fifty-five with
seven years service.
(Passed 5-8-97.)
151.07 PAY PERIOD. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
151.07 was repealed by Ordinance 01-17.
151.08 DRUGS, NARCOTICS AND ALCOHOL POLICY.
   (a)   Employees are prohibited from the illegal use, sale, dispensing,
distribution, possession or manufacture of illegal drugs, controlled
substances, narcotics, or alcoholic beverages. In addition, the City prohibits
off-premises abuse of alcohol and controlled substances, as well as the
possession, use, or sale of illegal drugs, when these activities adversely
affect performance, safety, or the City’s reputation in the community.
   (b)   The City will not grant employment, subject to state or local law
restrictions, to alcoholics or drug abusers whose current use of those
substances prevents them from performing or who would constitute a direct
threat to the property or safety of others. Whenever applicants are to be
tested for the presence of illegal drugs or alcohol, they are to be informed in
advance and in writing.
   (c)   Employees will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including
termination, for violations of this policy. Violations include, but are not
limited to, possessing illegal or controlled substances and narcotics or
alcoholic beverages while on City premises; being under the influence of those
substances while on City premises; using them while working; or dispensing,
distributing or illegally manufacturing or selling them on City premises and
work sites.
   (d)   Employees subject to the Drug-Free Workplace Act who are convicted of
any criminal drug violation occurring in the workplace must report the
conviction to the City within five days, and the City will take appropriate
action.
   (e)   Employees, their possessions, and City-issued equipment and containers
under their control are subject to search and surveillance at all times while
on City premises or work sites or while conducting City business.
   (f)   Employees may be asked to take a test at any time to determine the
presence of drugs, narcotics or alcohol, unless the tests are prohibited by
law. Employees must sign a consent form authorizing the test and the City’s use
of the test results for purposes of administering its discipline policy. It is
a violation of this policy to refuse consent for these purposes or to test
positive for alcohol or illegal drugs. Policy violations will result in
discipline and may result in termination. Tests that are paid for by the City
are the property of the City, and the examination records will be treated as
confidential and held in separate medical files. However, records of specific
examinations will be made available, if required by law or regulation, to the
member, persons designated and authorized by the member, public agencies,
relevant insurance companies or the member’s doctor.
(Res. 10-04. Passed 7-22-04.)
151.09 LEAVE DONATION PROGRAM.
   (a)   The intent of this program is to provide a means to assist employees
who, because of long-term personal illness or that of an immediate family
member, have exhausted their leave benefits and would otherwise be subject to a
severe loss of income during a continuing absence from work.
   (b)   In order to donate accrued personal leave, an employee must meet all
the following eligibility criteria:
      (1)   Must be employed full time by the City of Vienna, for one year.
      (2)   Must have a minimum retained balance of 200 hours of combined leave
which includes sick, and vacation time, after making the deduction.
   (c)   Donations must be made in full day (8-hour) units. The maximum
donation is up to 160 hours for each recipient annually.
   (d)   The City may not disclose the identity of donors. Employees may not
donate time that has not yet been earned. Note: Donated leave is taken from the
donor’s balance at the time it is needed by the recipient, not necessarily at
the time of the donation.
   (e)   In order to receive donated leave, an employee must meet the following
eligibility criteria:
      (1)   Must be a full time employee of the City for at least one full
year.
      (2)   Be absent due to a non-occupational personal injury or disability
or that of an immediate family member, for which medical documentation
satisfactory to management is submitted.
      (3)   Have exhausted all personal accrued leave.
      (4)   Be expected to continue to be absent for an extended period of
time.
      (5)   Must not have had any disciplinary actions or unsatisfactory
performance evaluations within the last three years.
         (Res. 15-05. Passed 6-23-05.)
151.10 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY PLAN.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Resolution R-3-13 passed January 15, 2013, the
City has developed an Equal Employment Opportunity Plan with the intent and
purpose of guiding management in achieving equal employment opportunity for
minorities and females. These guidelines shall also apply to all grants
received by the City of Vienna from the U.S. Department of Justice as well as
any other applicable grant program.)
ARTICLE 153
Freedom of Information
153.01   Findings.
153.02   Scope.
153.03   Definitions.
153.04   Processing of FOIA requests.
153.05   Alternative dispositions of a FOIA request.
153.06   Time to respond to a FOIA request; extension of time to respond.
153.07   Fees.
153.08   Exemptions.
153.01 FINDINGS.
   The City Council finds that the fundamental philosophy of the American
constitutional form of representative government is the principle that
government is the servant of the people, and not the master of them. It
therefore is hereby declared to be the public policy of the City of Vienna,
West Virginia, that all persons are, unless otherwise expressly provided by
law, entitled to full and complete information regarding the affairs of
government and the official acts of those who represent them as public
officials and employees. The City Council, in order to assure that the City in
a timely manner provides complete and correct information relating to the
business of the City, does hereby enact this ordinance to standardize
procedures within the City of Vienna associated with processing Freedom of
Information Act requests.
(Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.02 SCOPE.
   This Article applies to all employees of the City, any individual or
organization charged with producing City FOIA responses, and contracted
organizations and individuals as their contracts may require compliance with
this Article or City policies generally.
(Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.03 DEFINITIONS.
   The definitions ascribed herein are applicable unless the context in which
used clearly
requires a different meaning. Additionally, the definitions in West Virginia
Code 29B-1-1 et seq. are equally applicable to this Article unless the context
in which the term is used clearly requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Addressee" means the person to whom the FOIA request is addressed.
   (b)   "City" means the City of Vienna, West Virginia.
   (c)   "Custodian" means the Mayor or the person designated by the Mayor to
be the custodian.
   (d)   "Department" means the following units of the City: Mayor, Recorder,
Finance Director, Fire Department, Police Department, Vienna Utility Board, and
Public Works Department.
   (e)   "FOIA" means the West Virginia Freedom Of Information Act (West
Virginia Code 29B-1-1 , et seq.).
   (f)   "Legal Counsel" means the attorney so designated by the Mayor.
   (g)   "Mayor'' means the Mayor of the City, or his or her designee.
   (h)   "Public record" includes any writing containing information relating
to the conduct of the public's business, prepared, owned and retained by a
public body.
   (i)   “Writing" includes any books, papers, maps, photographs, cards, tapes,
recordings or other documentary materials regardless of physical form or
characteristics.
   (j)   "FOIA request" means an oral or written statement or question,
including an e-mail, to the City for inspection or copying of one or more of
the City's records.
   (k)   "Requester" means a person filing a FOIA request for City Records.
      (Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.04 PROCESSING OF FOIA REQUESTS.
   (a)   FOIA requests shall be addressed to the Mayor, as custodian of the
records requested.
      (1)   If a FOIA request is received by a Department employee, he or she
shall immediately refer the FOIA request to his or her Department Head who
shall immediately forward the FOIA request to the Mayor. The FOIA request shall
then be processed as directed in this section and Section
153.05  of this Article.
   (b)   Upon receipt of a FOIA request, the Mayor shall:
      (1)   Record the date the FOIA request was received and establish a file
for the FOIA request;
      (2)   Forward the FOIA request to the appropriate Department Head for
collection of the requested information.
         A.   If a Department Head, or his or her designee, thinks a FOIA
request was misdirected by the Mayor's Office to the Department, he or she
shall immediately call the Mayor's Office for instructions.
         B.   When the requested information has been collected, the Department
Head shall immediately forward the information to the Mayor;
      (3)   If the request is for records that may be in more than one
Department, the FOIA request also shall be forwarded to the other relevant
Department Heads. The Mayor shall select a lead Department to collect the
requested records from all relevant Departments and inform the other relevant
Department Heads regarding the identity of the designated lead Department;
      (4)   Send the appropriate Department Head the copies of any Records in
the Mayor's office that are responsive to the FOIA request; and
      (5)   If the FOIA request is related to a potentially controversial or
sensitive matter, send a copy of the FOIA request to the Legal Counsel and, if
necessary, request guidance from the legal counsel for a determination of the
applicability of West Virginia Code § 29B-1-4 relating to information exempt
from FOIA or other provisions of law, court orders, or court recognized
privileges, such as attorney-client, attorney work-product, deliberative
process, etc.
         (Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.05 ALTERNATIVE DISPOSITIONS OF A FOIA REQUEST.
   (a)   The disposition of a FOIA request may be accomplished by:
      (1)   Notifying the requester in writing that the FOIA request lacks
reasonable specificity to identify the records requested;
      (2)   Notifying the requester in writing that the requested records are
not possessed by the City;
      (3)   Notifying the requester in writing where the requested records may
be obtained from the City's website or other websites;
      (4)   Notifying the requester in writing of the time and place at which
he or she may inspect and make copies of records;
      (5)   Furnishing copies of the requested records in accordance with the
law and this Article, as well as providing an invoice stating the fee that is
due;
      (6)   Responding to the requester in writing when the requested records
are relevant to a suit or grievance against the City; or
      (7)   Denying the request in writing, in whole or in part.
   (b)   The response shall include statements that notify the requester:
      (1)   The reasons for the denial, if the requested records are not
provided;
      (2)   That the responsibility of the City to produce the requested
records is at an end; and
      (3)   That the requester may institute proceedings in the Circuit Court
of the jurisdiction where the Records are kept, i.e., the Circuit Court of Wood
County, West Virginia.
   (c)   A copy of the response, whether it provides the requested information
or denies the request for information, shall be maintained in the office of the
Recorder.
(Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.06 TIME TO RESPOND TO A FOIA REQUEST; EXTENSION OF TIME TO RESPOND.
   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in this Article, a response to a FOIA
request must
be made within five days of receipt of the Request by the City, not including
the day of receipt, Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays.
   (b)   If the Custodian determines that the requested records cannot be
retrieved and
copied before the response is due, the Custodian shall;
      (1)   Process the FOIA request in conformance with Section
153.05  of this Article;
      (2)   Attempt to contact the Requester by telephone or e-mail to:
         A.   Provide any fee information required by Section
153.08  of this Article;
         B.   Explain why the response cannot be timely prepared;
         C.   Provide an estimated time when the response will be ready.
      (3)   Send a letter or e-mail to the Requester documenting any telephone
conversation, including any fee information required by Section
153.07  of this Article; and
      (4)   If there was no telephone conversation or e-mail reply, send a
letter to the requester containing the information and request that would have
been provided in the telephone call.
         (Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
153.07 FEES.
   (a)   Fees for copies of requested Records are as follows:
      (1)   Each page is to be furnished at a charge of twenty-five cents
($0.25) per page printed on 8 ½" x 11" or 8 ½" x 14" paper.
      (2)   Records reproduced on larger paper, tape recordings, videos or any
other type of format other than the method described in subsection (b)(1)
above, are provided at actual cost, which includes but may not be limited to,
materials, the operator’s time, transportation, fees charged by outside
entities, and delivery charges.
   (b)   The City Recorder or the Mayor shall have the discretion to determine
if no fee shall be charged for a follow-up request because incorrect,
inadequate or inaccurate information was provided in the response to the
original FOIA request.
   (c)   Fees may be waived only by the City Recorder or the Mayor.
   (d)   The fee when received shall be forwarded to the City Finance Director.
All correspondence, including e-mail, and the response to the requester, shall
be filed with and retained by the Custodian.
   (e)   All fees charged for accident reports and photographs generated by the
Vienna Police Department, whether on a disk or otherwise, shall be five dollars
($5.00) per report. If the report, including photographs, is in excess of
twenty pages, the fee is five dollars ($5.00) per report plus twenty-five cents
($0.25) for each page over twenty.
(Ord. 03-17. Passed 4-27-17.)
153.08 EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   The following categories of information are specifically exempt from
disclosure under the provisions of the West Virginia Freedom Of Information Act
(West Virginia Code 29B-1-1 et seq.) and this article:
      (1)   Trade secrets, as used in this section, which may include, but are
not limited to, any formula, plan pattern, process, tool, mechanism, compound,
procedure, production data or compilation of information which is not patented
which is known only to certain individuals within a commercial concern who are
using it to fabricate, produce or compound an article or trade or a service or
to locate minerals or other substances, having commercial value, and which
gives its users an opportunity to obtain business advantage over competitors;
      (2)   Information of a personal nature such as that kept in a personal,
medical or similar file, if the public disclosure thereof would constitute an
unreasonable invasion of privacy, unless the public interest by clear and
convincing evidence requires disclosure in the particular instance: Provided,
That nothing in this article shall be construed as precluding an individual
from inspecting or copying his or her own personal, medical or similar file;
      (3)   Test questions, scoring keys and other examination data used to
administer a licensing examination, examination for employment or academic
examination;
      (4)   Records of law-enforcement agencies that deal with the detection
and investigation of crime and the internal records and notations of such law-
enforcement agencies which are maintained for internal use in matters relating
to law enforcement;
      (5)   Information specifically exempted from disclosure by statute;
      (6)   Records, archives, documents or manuscripts describing the location
of undeveloped historic, prehistoric, archaeological, paleontological and
battlefield sites or constituting gifts to any public body upon which the donor
has attached restrictions on usage or the handling of which could irreparably
damage such record, archive, document or manuscript;
      (7)   Information contained in or related to examination, operating or
condition reports prepared by, or on behalf of, or for the use of any agency
responsible for the regulation or supervision of financial institutions, except
those reports which are by law required to be published in newspapers;
      (8)   Internal memoranda or letters received or prepared by any public
body;
      (9)   Records assembled, prepared or maintained to prevent, mitigate or
respond to terrorist acts or the threat of terrorist acts, the public
disclosure of which threaten the public safety or the public health;
      (10)   Those portions of records containing specific or unique
vulnerability assessments or specific or unique response plans, data, databases
and inventories of goods or materials collected or assembled to respond to
terrorist acts; and communication codes or deployment plans of law enforcement
or emergency response personnel;
      (11)   Specific intelligence information and specific investigative
records dealing with terrorist acts or the threat of a terrorist act shared by
and between federal and international law-enforcement agencies, state and local
law enforcement and other agencies within the Department of Military Affairs
and Public Safety;
      (12)   National security records classified under federal executive order
and not subject to public disclosure under federal law that are shared by
federal agencies and other records related to national security briefings to
assist state and local government with domestic preparedness for acts of
terrorism;
      (13)   Computing, telecommunications and network security records,
passwords, security codes or programs used to respond to or plan against acts
of terrorism which may be the subject of a terrorist act;
      (14)   Security or disaster recovery plans, risk assessments, tests or
the results of those tests;
      (15)   Architectural or infrastructure designs, maps or other records
that show the location or layout of the facilities where computing,
telecommunications or network infrastructure used to plan against or respond to
terrorism are located or planned to be located;
      (16)   Codes for facility security systems; or codes for secure
applications for such facilities referred to in subdivision (15) of this
subsection;
      (17)   Specific engineering plans and descriptions of existing public
utility plants and equipment; and
      (18)   Customer proprietary network information of other
telecommunications carriers, equipment manufacturers and individual customers,
consistent with 47 U.S.C. §222.
   (b)   As used in subsections (a)(9) through (18), the term "terrorist act"
means an act that is likely to result in serious bodily injury or damage to
property or the environment and is intended to:
      (1)   Intimidate or coerce the civilian population;
      (2)   Influence the policy of a branch or level of government by
intimidation or coercion;
      (3)   Affect the conduct of a branch or level of government by
intimidation or coercion; or
      (4)   Retaliate against a branch or level of government for a policy or
conduct of the government.
   (c)   Nothing in the provisions of subsections (a)(9) through (18), should
be construed to make subject to the provisions of this Article any evidence of
an immediate threat to public health or safety unrelated to a terrorist act or
the threat thereof which comes to the attention of a public entity in the
course of conducting a vulnerability assessment response or similar activity.
(Ord. 05-14. Passed 4-24-14.)
CHAPTER SEVEN - Judicial
Art.
173. Police Court.
ARTICLE 173
Police Court
 
173.01    Created.
173.02    Police Judge: appointment, compensation, oath, bond.
173.03    Powers and duties.
173.04    Docket; disposition of fees, fines and costs.
173.05    Costs for violations.
173.06    Right of appeal.
173.07    Court costs; special arrest fee.
173.08    Posting appearance bonds.
173.09   City Court Clerk to act as substitute Police Court Judge.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code 8-10-2
Powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8-10-1; 8-10-2
Arrest fee - see W. Va. Code 8-22-20
Appeals - see W. Va. Code 8-34-1
 
 
173.01 CREATED.
   There is hereby created a Police Court for the City, which shall be presided
over by a Police Judge. (1965 Code §2-33)
173.02 POLICE JUDGE: APPOINTMENT, COMPENSATION, OATH, BOND.
   There shall be a Police Judge appointed by Council by resolution, who shall
hold his office at the pleasure of Council and who shall receive such
compensation as may be fixed by Council. The person so appointed as Police
Judge shall qualify by taking the oath of office and shall give bond in an
amount fixed by Council, under which bond he shall be responsible for all funds
coming into his hands by virtue of the appointment.
(1965 Code §2-34)
173.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Police Judge shall have such powers and perform such duties as may be
prescribed or conferred by any law of the State or by ordinance of the City.
(1965 Code §2-35)
173.04 DOCKET, DISPOSITION OF FEES, FINES AND COSTS.
   There shall be a docket of the Police Court, and the Police Judge shall
docket fully thereon all cases in the Court and show thereon all fees, fines
and costs adjudged and collected. The Police Judge shall, at least once a
month, make a written report to the City Treasurer showing all receipts for the
previous month and shall pay over and deliver to the Treasurer all moneys so
received and to which the City is entitled. Each report shall be presented to
Council at its next regular meeting.
(1965 Code §2-36)
173.05 COSTS FOR VIOLATIONS.
   The City shall be entitled to, and the Police Judge may tax, in all cases
appearing before him involving violations of City ordinances, such costs
authorized by law.
(1965 Code §2-37)
173.06 RIGHT OF APPEAL.
   Every person sentenced by the Police Judge to imprisonment or to the payment
of a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more, and in no case shall a fine of less
than ten dollars ($10.00) be imposed if the defendant, his agent or attorney
objects thereto, shall be allowed an appeal to the Circuit Court as provided by
West Virginia Code 8-34-1.
(1965 Code §2-38)
173.07 COURT COSTS; SPECIAL ARREST FEE.
   In cases of the conviction for violation of any provision of the Codified
Ordinances or other municipal ordinance or any State law of any person arrested
by any member of the Police Department, or the forfeiture of bail not vacated
after arrest for violation of any provision of the Codified Ordinances or other
Municipal ordinance or any State law by any person so arrested, an arrest fee
of one dollar ($1.00) shall be taxed as part of the costs, in addition to other
fees authorized by law, and shall be collected from the person convicted or
furnishing bail, and such arrest fee shall be paid into the Policemen's Pension
or Relief Fund, as prescribed in West Virginia Code 8-22-20.
(1965 Code §1-13)
173.08 POSTING APPEARANCE BONDS.
   The duplicate receipt book method shall be used for the posting of
appearance bonds in all cases arising under the provisions of the Codified
Ordinances or other City ordinances.
(1965 Code §1-14)
173.09 CITY COURT CLERK TO ACT AS SUBSTITUTE POLICE COURT JUDGE.
   (a)   In the absence of, or the inability of the regular Police Court Judge
to perform his or her duties, the City Court Clerk is hereby designated as
Substitute Police Court Judge to act in cases and perform the duties of the
said regular judge of the municipal court. The oath of office for the Clerk
shall be administered by the regular judge.
 
   (b)   Should the City Clerk not have been admitted to practice law in this
State, he or she shall, prior to assuming the duties of Substitute Police Court
Judge, attend and complete the next available course of instruction in
rudimentary principles of law and procedure, pursuant to the requirements of
West Virginia law, presently set forth in W. Va. Code §8-10- 2.
(Ord. 08-15. Passed 9-10-15.)
